The defendants say, I didn't do it , and the government presents their evidence and say,
"That defense is nonsense. "
"We presented overwhelming evidence. "
In fact, in this case, also they did -- they didn't ask in the instruction because they thought it was our burden.
They agreed in the end that the jury should be instructed--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: I think the crux of your argument is that the government is going to have to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, active participation in the conspiracy during the statute of limitations period, because it is impossible for the prosecution to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that on no day during a five-year period did the defendant withdraw from the conspiracy.
It simply can't be done.
This person was under 24-hour video surveillance for the whole five-year period.

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: --All they have to prove, Justice Alito, is that the person was a member of the conspiracy within the limitations period.
That could be done by the inference that they were a member outside the limitations period and say that there was just insufficient -- that the--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And say what?
That there was insufficient evidence to prove--

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --the opposite of what they have to prove?

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: No.
That they -- insufficient evidence doesn't create a reasonable doubt in what they are required to prove, which is membership within the limitations period.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: I thought you argue that every day that there is -- that something has to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt because the prosecution hasn't provided sufficient evidence?

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: It is.
And the prosecution stands up and says,
"We presented plenty of evidence that -- that there is no reasonable doubt here at all. "
And that happens every day, needless to say, that people are convicted by that argument when--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, Mr. Kramer, if they really have to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that there is membership in the conspiracy during the limitations period, they couldn't just come in and say,
"Well, there's membership in the conspiracy before the limitations period, and, you know, you should assume that it continued. "
I mean that's not a beyond-a-reasonable-doubt kind of proof, is it?

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: --They get a permissive inference.
And there are many cases when I think that would be proof beyond a reasonable doubt for a jury.
Absent some conflicting evidence presented by the defendant, more than just a proffer.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Couldn't you argue they have the burden of proving that the defendant did not withdraw during this five-year period?
They have the burden of proving that.
And did you hear any evidence from them that -- did you hear evidence disproving that -- that he didn't withdraw during that period?
There is no evidence on that.

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: Of course--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: You can make that argument?

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: --Yes.
Or did we prove -- did you hear any evidence that there was no evidence that Mr. Smith was a member during the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Your -- I'm sorry, the Thomas Crown Affair again, all the evidence shows he took $10,000 from the bank.
He testifies and says,
"Oh, I was going to give it back. "
Okay?
The prosecution puts on nothing.
The jury says, Are you kidding ?

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: a_j_kramer
turn.label: Mr. A. J. Kramer
turn.text: I mean, and that happens every day, I think, in cases where the prosecution just stands up and says,
"You heard that evidence. "
"Nobody would think that is a reasonable doubt that someone was not a member. "
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
